TopicTitle: What is wrong with this orbit?

Articles.Content:
I'm doing this contract to put a probe in to orbit, the orbit looks pretty much perfect to me ( i know the periapsis and apoapsis are a bit off , thats becasue i was trying to find the problem before my fuel ran out). It says the inclination should be 154.7  degrees in the contract but mechjeb says it is 25 degrees or so, and honestly i don't know what that really means. Do i need the probe to be going in the opposite direction or something? 

Edited November 5, 2016 by DanTheMan96
Hard to see but maybe you're just orbiting in the wrong direction.
The inclination of the target orbit is 154.7°, yours is 25°. You're orbiting the wrong way around. (Any inclination greater than 90° indicates a retrograde orbit)
The An and Dn numbers on the satellite orbit tell you how close you are. When you are perfectly lined up, they should say 0 degrees. If they say 180, then you're backwards, yup.

Any orbit inclination greater than 90 degrees is a retrograde orbit. Also, the projected orbit in the map view should show a sort of gradient (I'm not exactly sure how to describe it) that rotates in the direction of the orbit.
